text: on the mend today hi everyone Anthony
Fantino here internet's busiest music
nerd time for a review Big KRIT forever
in a day Big KRIT is a Mississippi
rapper who's been bringing back the
classier side of southern hip hop in a
big way for the past couple years he's
been making mixtapes for a while but a
little bit he really started making
waves in 2010 when he put out his album
crit was here and he gained even more
ground with a Def Jam signing and return
of forever in 2011 and the dude's output
so far has just been incredibly
consistent just really solid stuff he
raps on his own stuff he sings a little
bit as well and he produces his own
instrumentals he is in complete control
of everything that goes into his music
so rarely do his tracks ever take an
unpredictable turn not to say that
there's not variety on here it's just
that I rarely hear a Big KRIT track that
I find out of character whether crit is
gone for something really smooth and
soulful like on the track highs and lows
or really hard-hitting and energetic
like the song country he's always
throwing production out there that has
this really smooth resonant bass crisp
eyes and a real strong southern flavor
the dude can produce and he's proven
himself as a songwriter too because he
puts some great infectious and extremely
catchy hooks on his tracks too I think
the weakest link in his chain for a lot
of people is his rapping his flows on
his records crit does not display
himself to be the most flashy spitter
out there though if you did check out
the double XL cypher or the ve T cypher
last year that he was involved in he
definitely held his own against the
other emcees that were there tons of
technical ability isn't really what Big
KRIT shoots for if you want to
understand what big crits appeal is
listen
to the verse he dropped on that roots
album that came out last year undone
vivid imagery storytelling passionate
emotions and it's all displayed in a way
where it's extremely extremely easy to
relate to for the listener whether big
Cree is rapping about the worst things
the world has to offer being successful
or even just a fantasy car he really
tries to put the listener in the
passenger seat TT a lot of the time this
gives Big KRIT songs really kind of
uplifting and inspirational quality to
them especially when he's rapping about
how far along he's come in his career
because he's really putting a real
picture of success out there because
it's not like climbing to the top is all
money models and expensive alcohol
success can be really fleeting
especially in the music industry and
unless you're completely clueless or
really egotistical you're going to have
a natural hunger to self-improve or
maybe just have some feelings of
self-doubt here and there that feeling
is kind of displayed on the first track
to drop from this album boobie miles
which is a song titled after a high
school tailback that was looking at a
pretty promising football career just
before it was ended by a knee injury
crit takes the track through a series of
sports analogies and ends up turning
into a word of advice that if you're
ever going to make it to where you want
to be you've got to be focused you've
got to be a relentless because you never
know when your competitions gonna creep
up those kinds of feelings play as big a
role in crits personal story as those
high end blissful feelings that come
with success
I actually think on this LP those
feelings play a little bit bigger of a
role it's almost like the further Crick
gets away from the ways life used to be
the more he gets nostalgic about it me
personally when listening to this thing
I was catching maybe a little bit more
referencing to his family and his
friends and his girlfriend as well
especially on tracks like yesterday and
red.i it's not a night and
a change though because crits usual
subject matters and lyrical topics make
it onto this LP too but this overly
sentimental attitude kind of comes
through on the instrumental side of this
LP to do here Big KRIT is sampling just
a little bit more smooth jazz R&B and
soul and it's given a lot of these
tracks a really strong emotional
foundation like the tracks boobie miles
and yesterday are just built on that Hot
Buttered Soul of guys like Isaac Hayes
Curtis Mayfield and Marvin Gaye the song
handwriting actually samples a sultry
cut from Annie and Peebles handwriting
is on the wall it's actually a track woo
Tang Clan sampled as well on their 2001
album iron flag the track red eye has
some really somber piano chords on it
and that's not the only track on here
that just has maybe a little bit more
atmosphere around it some shimmering
instrumentation some prettier sounds
just some more high gloss Sheen the
track me in my old school even has these
reverb soaked flute solos kind of
fluttering all over the place in between
these cascading layers of string
sections I think it's definitely the
prettiest instrumental big Critias put
together so far crit even invites guest
musicians onto this LP to perform on on
these tracks the song wake up has some
are some more familiar sounds on this
thing though like the track forever and
a day the title track which sounds like
a variation of the title track from big
crits previous album same with the songs
1986 and country rap tunes those songs
also kind of feel like different takes
on crits usual sound but different
enough to still kind of be enjoyable
especially 1986 which has a really
interesting change up in the beat toward
the end of the track it's almost like it
changes into a totally different song
toward the end but one of the most
exciting songs on here or maybe the most
affecting songs on here for me is
definitely packaged store the opening
bar on that track about the preacher
trying to pick up a prostitute with
collection money from the church
is just so dark and and twisted
especially when it's kind of backed up
with the light about snakes in the grass
too in the last track on here the closer
the alarm is kind of like this really
just fiery intense philosophical wake-up
call there's this really kind of
operatic vocal toward the end of the
track and this instrumental swell that's
that's pretty gorgeous overall the album
is great but if I had to get a little
nitpicky with it some tracks did kind of
pale in comparison to others definitely
tracks like wake up and yesterday could
have developed a little bit more got a
little bit more detail into the
instrumental as the song progressed some
spots here felt maybe a little bit too
lovesick I felt like the last track
could have used a lot more lyrics but
still I enjoyed this a lot this was
great and between this Return to Forever
and chritmas here this guy has been on
an incredible streak it's only kind of
making the build-up to his kind of major
label debut live from the underground
even more intense to me just feeling a
decent too strong eight on this thing
what do you guys think about it did you
love it did you hate it why and what
should I review next anthony Fantana Big
KRIT forever and a day forever
[Music]
